data.title: Alphatec Holdings: Buy On Solid Results And Outlook
data.description:
Note:

I have discussed Alphatec Holdings, Inc. (NASDAQ:ATEC) previously, so investors should view this article as an update to my earlier coverage of the company.

Alphatec Holdings, Inc. or "ATEC" is a medical technology company that designs, develops, and advances technologies for the surgical treatment of spinal disorders.

In recent years, ATEC has successfully grown market share and outperformed sales expectations on a regular basis.

Unfortunately, growth has come at a price, as evidenced by persistently negative free cash flow in recent years. Please note that numbers have been adjusted for acquisitions:

However, things have been moving in the right direction over the course of 2025 as also evidenced by this week's fourth quarter and full year financial results:

Fourth quarter sales of $212.9 million and Adjusted EBITDA of $33.1 million represented new multi-year highs for the company.

ATEC generated $7.7 million in free cash flow and ended the year with $160.8 million in cash and cash equivalents and $691.7 million in funded debt. The company's $60 million revolving credit facility remained undrawn.

On the conference call, management guided for continued growth, albeit at a more measured pace:

Please note that ATEC has outperformed initial sales guidance for seven consecutive years now. Should this pattern persist, 2026 growth might be well north of 20% again.

Management also projected substantial improvements in profitability with Adjusted EBITDA expected to increase by almost 50% this year:

However, required investments in working capital and higher capital expenditures will limit cash generation. That said, the company's free cash flow guidance of $20 million still represents a substantial increase over the $3 million generated in 2025.

Please note that ATEC will have to redeem the remaining $63.25 million of its 2026 0.75% convertible notes on August 1.

While the company has sufficient cash on hand to deal with the convertible notes maturity, favorable market conditions might very well cause management to consider a refinancing transaction.

However, I do not expect an outright equity offering at this point.

Valuation-wise, ATEC is currently trading at approximately 14x my 2027 EV/Adjusted EBITDA estimate, which is well below the average of the U.S. healthcare product industry.

Assigning the industry average of 20x would yield a $20 price target:

While expectations for moderating growth and rather limited cash generation might have alienated some investors as of late, I don't consider this a cause for concern, particularly not given the company's long-standing pattern of outperforming sales targets.

In my opinion, the recent weakness in the shares has presented another buying opportunity. Should ATEC continue to outperform expectations, I would expect the stock price to return to recent highs above $20.

Consequently, I am reiterating my "Buy" rating on the company's shares while increasing my price target from $18.00 to $20.00.

Risks

As usual, the bull thesis is not without risks. Should the company fail to deliver on growth and profitability expectations, the stock price will almost certainly take a major hit.

Bottom Line

Once again, Alphatec Holdings outperformed growth expectations in 2025. In addition, the company delivered vastly improved profitability and cash flow.

While expectations for moderately lower growth in 2026 have caused shares to drop in recent weeks, investors should remember the company's long-standing pattern of outperforming sales expectations.

With management projecting an almost 50% increase in Adjusted EBITDA this year, I would consider the recent selloff a buying opportunity.

As a result, I am reiterating my "Buy" rating on the shares while increasing my price target from $18.00 to $20.00.

data.title: Verizon's Growth Inflection: Up 22% This Year. Here's What's Next
data.description:
Written by Sam Kovacs.

Introduction

Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) is up 22% year to date.

Meanwhile the S&P 500 (SPY) and the Nasdaq (QQQ) are both negative.

What's going on with Verizon? Is the rerating done, or just getting started?

That's what this article will look at.

Bullish take:

Verizon has been a core holding for us at the Dividend Freedom Tribe. Since my last public article on the stock in April 2024, Verizon has returned more in total than the S&P 500.

And here is the thing: the market was as wrong as ever as VZ. We've been collecting this big dividend whilst waiting for the stock to rerate, which has now convincingly started.

But here's the thing: a rerating to its 2012 - 2020 levels would mean a price target in the $60 to $70.

It's currently priced at $49.8.

That would imply up to 40% upside from a bullish rerating, on top of the 5.8% yield that you collect.

At this point, you're thinking "sure sounds nice Sam, but how do we get from $50 to $70?"

Here's how.

The one number that tells the story:

In 2026, Verizon will likely generate $21.5bn in free cash flow.

This would be 7% up from 2025. This marks a clear inflection for Verizon, and it doesn't depend on any heroic operating performance.

The bridge from $20.1bn to $21.5bn is pretty clear: Verizon's facing a CAPEX cliff. A little improvement in EBITDA will help, and gives the scope for the "or more" mention after $21.5bn.

Operating cashflow could be up from $37.1bn to $38bn.

So this $21.5bn in free cashflow on a $206bn market cap buys you a 10.4% free cashflow yield.

The dividend costs them $12bn. They'll probably buy back at least $3bn in shares (a drop in the water relative to market cap). That will leaves over $6bn for the company to pay down its debt.

With the risk free rate at 3.6%, you're getting a full 2.2% more right now with Verizon, for a business which is getting FCF returns equal to 10% market cap.

Sure debt service is a big one at $131bn total debt. From $3.5bn of interest expenses in 2021, VZ's interest bill has swollen to likely $7bn in 2026.

From $38bn in operating expenses, that's quite a bite. But VZ is a cashflow machine which can easily beat the hurdle. If it had to it could stop the buyback and pay another 50% in interest without affecting the dividend whatsoever.

So yes lower rates would be a tailwind. Higher for longer continue to hold the financials back a bit, but they do not cause existential risks to VZ's dividend policy.

The Frontier acquisition adds a growth kicker

Before acquiring Frontier, VZ could only bundle wireless and fiber in 9 states.

These "converged" customers are much stickier. They churn at half the rate Which makes sense, if you have everything going through Verizon, you probably don't bother with switching so easily.

With Frontier, VZ can offer bundles in 31 states.

This is a true win win for VZ and its customers, as it can reduce customer spend by bundling, increase average revenue per user and decrease churn.

That's why having Schulman who's ex-PayPal at the helm makes sense: he understands the metrics that change the math on recurring subscription businesses.

Management has clearly expressed that this will be Verizon's growth trajectory going forward. Good to see them turning away from a price hike campaign and into an increasing the value proposition campaign.

T-Mobile (T) has no fiber to compete, and AT&T (T) has a smaller fiber footprint, which is creating a deeper moat for VZ that will take market share from this structural reshuffling of the offering.

On top of all this, management expects $1bn of synergies by 2028. Even without the synergies, it makes sense.

Conclusion: The tide has already turned

VZ has yielded as much as 8.6% in the past 3 years. During the past 5 years it has yielded on average 6.4%. Today it yields 5.8%.

The yield has been compressing, which is to say that the price has been increasing.

Verizon is undergoing a rerating, but the market hasn't fully appreciated it.

They grew the dividend by 4.4%, which if can be maintained justifies a yield of 4-4.5%, which would suggest a $70 price tag.

While we've been picking up shares at below $40 over the years at the DFT, we have a target for buying below until it hits $52.5.

That means VZ is still in our buy zone, and I think a terrific time to add to the stock.

data.title: International Tower Hill Mines As A Cheap Lever On The Price Of Gold, A Change Worth $115 Million
data.description:
THM as a leveraged bet on gold with increasing probability of realization

I see International Tower Hill Mines (THM) as a form of gold derivative. The company has currently moved from the stage of promising potential to the stage where it makes sense to talk about implementation and value creation. This has happened mainly thanks to the large and already partially transferred audit base. It is also thanks to a large capital increase, which effectively extends the runway and allows the company to do work that the market can appreciate. Last but not least, I would like to mention the visibility of antimony as a potential co-product at a time when the domestic supply chain of strategic metals is politically and economically unstable.

My rating is based on a simple idea. The market usually prices development projects with a heavy discount, and in most cases, it does so brutally. Until it is clear who will pay for it and who will approve it. At THM, the first such block has just moved, the company has closed an upsized equity financing ($115 million), and at the same time, it is clear that large and strong investors are willing to add to their positions. Of course, this in itself does not solve the main obstacle in the form of billions in capex. However, it reduces the risk of an immediate death spiral of financing and increases the chance that the project will move to a stage where it can be financed normally (partnerships, debt, offtake, etc.).

What I like most about the company is that it holds an asset that is easily readable for big players. P&P reserves are approximately 9 Moz. To this we can add M&I resources outside these reserves. This is exactly the type of foundation on which transactions can be built if the project team proves that it can improve the economics and reduce permitting uncertainty.

Bearings are not a problem, financing is the problem

International Tower Hill Mines is a single asset investment. The company holds a 100% stake in the Livengood Gold Project in Alaska. Livengood is located approximately 70 miles north of Fairbanks and is accessible by paved road. The whole story here comes down to one question, can Livengood move from being a large, capital heavy deposit to becoming a project that actually makes economic sense? I’ve looked at a few similar names before, including Vista Gold Corp. (VGZ) and Hycroft Mining Holding Corp. (HYMC), and there are useful parallels there that also help frame this case.

Considering that this is a junior player, the project's ratios are more than satisfactory. P&P 9 Moz Au (430.1 Mt @ 0.65 g/t, at a reference gold price of $1680 Oz) and, in addition, resources outside the M&I reserves of 4.62 Moz (274.51 Mt @ 0.52 t/g). In other words, the size of the deposit is not a problem; the problem is the economics of the project at realistic costs, especially financing in the permitting phase.

THM is back in the game right now because in January 2026, they closed $115 million in upscaled financing through a combination of a public offering and a private placement. Importantly, the transaction documents explicitly describe the intended use of the funds.

PFS shows high upside, but only with successful de-risking

THM is a project developer, and that is important to keep in mind. Because market valuation will primarily be based not on quarterly results, but on how quickly the company can move Livengood to a state where the project is financeable along with the permit. There are two sides to this type of investment. One is enormous leverage on the price of gold, and the other is enormous leverage on Capex and Cost of Capital. This is one of the reasons why THM makes sense to me, because the risk-reward ratio here is asymmetrical compared to other options.

The key document for understanding the company's current valuation is the PFS, which was published in 2021 and subsequently revised in subsequent technical reports. The PFS puts on paper what the market has been thinking for years, capex is massive. The estimate for initial capex was $1.93 billion, sustaining capex is $658 million, and reclamation & closure is $322 million. AISC life of mine comes out to $1,171/oz in the first 5 years.

And that is why the company has behaved like a high beta proxy for gold in the past. With lower gold prices and higher capital discounts, it looks like a very bad investment. But with higher gold prices and the market's willingness to finance long-term projects, it looks like massive leverage on the price of gold without the use of options.

The following sensitivity is presented in the PFS:

  • $1,500/oz, after tax NPV (5%) is minus $512 million, IRR -1%, payback 16.2 years
  • $1,800/oz, after tax NPV (5%) is approximately $400 million, IRR +7.7%, payback 8.2 years
  • $2000/oz, after tax NPV (5%) is approximately $975 million, IRR +11.2%, payback 6.3 years
  • $2500/oz, after tax NPV (5%) is approximately $2.351 billion, IRR +18.5%, payback 3.9 years

The core of my thesis is therefore that THM is a proxy for a long duration gold asset. From this perspective, it is important that the company has raised fresh capital for work that increases the likelihood that this will become a realistically financeable project, rather than just a model in a PDF.

In January 2026, the company closed an upsizing of equity financing worth approximately $115 million, with the use of these funds being explicit. The funds will be used for drilling, metallurgy, feasibility, baseline environmental, detail engineering for permitting, legal support, community engagement, and payments for mineral leases. These are exactly the kinds of steps that can make the project more financeable and improve the odds of bringing in a partner. Personally, I was pleased with this financing because it shows that the big players are willing to keep up. Of course, this in itself does not guarantee success, but it increases the chance that the next steps will not be blind again.

I also mentioned antimony. I see the antimony mineralization as a potential way to improve the project’s economics and possibly make the asset more attractive for future partnerships. The company announced encouraging results from the first phase, where they achieved liberation in the range of p80 - 250 microns in 54 stibnite veins. As in other cases I have written about previously, such as VGZ or HYMC, I am glad that they are trying to address the issue of how to increase the value of each ton mined without disrupting the simplicity of the entire process.

THM is no longer concerned with survival, but with the effective use of capital

Since the company has no revenue, we will focus primarily on liquidity, cash burn, and cap table. This information will show us whether the company will expand or just survive.

For a long time, the company was a typical junior in the "let's save every $100k" mode. In December 2024, the company reported cash & equivalents of $0.992 million and working capital of $0.96 million. Management also made it clear that the company had no revenue generating operations and was still reliant on equity financing. Cash briefly increased to $2.28 million during 2025, but that still was not enough to meaningfully advance the project. The real inflection point came in January 2026, when THM completed a $115 million financing.

For 2024, the company reported a net loss of $3.599 million. From a liquidity standpoint, the key point is that management explicitly said the decline in cash was driven mainly by roughly $2.9 million used in operating activities.

Paradoxically, this is both good and bad news for potential investors.

The good news is that G&A has remained at relatively decent levels from the developers' perspective. The MD&A shows that share-based payments ($613.7k) are a large item and that current operating costs are in the range of a few million per year. The bad news is that after January's financing, the burn rate will increase because it is no longer a matter of survival but of paying for technical and support services. The original cash burn will increase from the original $2 million to $4 million per year to tens of millions per year, with the rate depending on the program.

If I translate this purely pragmatically, the company originally dealt with money on a monthly basis, but now the horizon has lengthened and finances can be dealt with over a period of years. From my perspective, that takes a lot of near-term pressure off the company and gives management more room to focus on longer-term objectives.

Now let’s look at the dilution from the January financing, which was completed at $2.22 per share.

The underwritten public offering was 29,280,000 shares, the underwriters' option was 4,392,000 shares, and the concurrent private placement was 18,018,018 shares (the buyer was Paulson & Co. Inc.). Paulson purchased $40 million worth of shares, and the company also reports that Paulson purchased an additional 1,501,982 shares for $3.3 million. At that time, THM had 207,885,473 outstanding shares. After the offering and concurrent PP, we reached 259,575,491 shares (an increase of +24.9%). In my view, this is relatively high dilution. However, it is necessary to distinguish between bad and good dilution. Bad dilution is when a company issues shares with the intention of merely surviving the next quarter.

Good dilution is when a company issues shares to pay for more work that reduces overall risk and may increase the likelihood of success. From my point of view, the most important thing now is to monitor the differences between actual capital expenditure and the submitted plan. Management has indicated that around $50 million will go toward feasibility related work, with another roughly $35 million earmarked for permitting and community engagement. That makes sense on paper, but the real issue is execution.

From here, the key metric is not just how much cash is spent but whether that spending leads to clear and measurable progress. If the burn rate starts to outrun visible deliverables, that would be the first sign that the story is going off track. We know from history that the burn rate was not extreme, but as we wrote above, that will change. Last but not least, it is necessary to take into account the overhang options. The prospectus lists options in the amount of 2,215,000 and DSU 3,476,102, which is not a devastating amount compared to 260 million shares, but it is good to keep it in mind and take into account the possible impact on the price.

THM valuation is not based on accounting, but on the probability of realization

With this company, it is not about P/E valuation or EBITDA. In our investment thesis, we have approached THM as a discounted project with an asymmetric risk-reward ratio. The size and quality of asset reserves compared to capex, cost of capital, and permitting risk are significant.

NPV (5%) is not just a model with an implicit cost of capital. For projects like this, with high capex and a long payback period, a 5% discount is extremely favorable. In practice, the market often implicitly uses a higher discount (8-12%) and adds a probability haircut for permitting and financing. Therefore, it is not surprising that THM has historically not traded anywhere near its NPV. Furthermore, gold is not currently trading at $1680/oz, but even that is still not reflected in the NPV on a 1:1 basis. Even though the spot price of gold is higher than the reference price in reserves, a developer without a clear path to financing and project implementation will not be valued as a finished producer. The market will not pay you the NPV, the market will pay the probability that it will ever reach the NPV. And that is the essential information, because THM bought time in January to make itself bankable.

It is certainly worth looking at the primitive parameter, which I have also used in other projects that I have analyzed and mentioned above. THM reports P&P reserves at 9Moz Au. For developers, we often see ranges between $20 and $100/oz (however, it depends greatly on the jurisdiction, grade, apex, inda, permitting, and, most importantly, the price of gold and sentiment).

EV per ounce is a primitive metric, but it is useful for checking whether a project is completely off track. Livengood is a low-grade, high-tonnage, high-capex project. This naturally pushes us into the lower half of EV/oz. It is important whether capex can be reduced, whether permitting will be feasible, and whether a partner will emerge who can handle the financing. Given the structure of THM as described above, EV/oz will not rise simply because the price of gold has gone up. THM becomes much more interesting as the odds of the project actually moving forward start to improve. In cases like this, I tend to think about valuation as project NPV adjusted for execution probability, with an added haircut for capex risk.

For THM to start being valued at higher multiples, approaching those of producers, there needs to be an overall improvement in feasibility, permitting, the conclusion of long-term partnerships, and the use of antimony. I am aware of gaps here which, if filled, could significantly advance the company. The broader backdrop is also becoming more supportive. With sentiment improving, geopolitics staying relevant, and gold holding up well, the project is starting to look more economically realistic, which could make THM more compelling to investors than it was before.

The main risk is not gold, but foreclosure

Since, as in other cases, this is only a project awaiting implementation, I consider it very important to mention the risks associated with a possible investment in THM. There are still risks associated with this company that have historically kept its valuation low and have long made THM more of a proxy leverage beta on the price of gold.

The company’s capex is so large that it puts serious pressure on the whole investment case unless the financing structure and other key assumptions improve. At the same time, that kind of imbalance is not unusual for a company of this size. However, this is a key risk that will end in disaster without a good partner and a smart financing structure. The market will never pay NPV until it sees that someone else is willing to put hundreds of millions and billions into a project with a long-term return, that long-term nature is key here. If THM keeps issuing more shares without clearly showing what progress is being made, I do not see much reason to stay in the position.

Next, I would like to mention the cost of inflation, which can render the PFS completely irrelevant, given that it dates from 2021. Since then, there have been significant changes in labor costs, material costs, energy prices, and the very structure of supply chains. In addition, the rate regime itself has changed, and with it the associated cost of capital. Even though the price of gold has risen, higher capex and higher discounts can wipe out a significant portion of these benefits. This is key information because the sensitive PFS shows that the project's economics are not concentrated around 0 but are extremely sensitive to inputs.

At lower gold prices, the NPV is negative, while at higher prices it is positive. This means that any shift in capex or discount will significantly reduce the resulting valuation. If management releases a newer project economics report where they make excuses about macroeconomics instead of presenting engagement, that's a red flag for me.

Although, from my point of view, management has been responsible within limits so far, I see another significant risk on the part of the execution itself. The company can burn through new cash without anything happening. The biggest risk after January's financing is not that the cash will run out, but that it will be spent and nothing will come of it. The new prospectuses clearly describe what is supposed to happen with the finances, but the question remains whether this will actually happen. If two quarters pass and the only communication is that we are continuing our work without any further concrete results, I will leave my position. The macro outlook for the price of the stock may be fine, but unfortunately that means nothing for THM.

Conclusions

In my opinion, stability is not about monitoring fundamentals, but about monitoring changes in probability that lead to successful implementation. The currently available information gives me an overall view that I rate as BUY. With its January financing, THM bought itself time and relatively large space to move Livengood from a geological asset to a state that the market can take seriously.

The key is that further potential upside no longer depends solely on the price of gold. Management has capital at its disposal that can achieve concrete de-risking, better feasibility, visible permitting, and the possible finding of partnerships. If this is truly successful, then the current valuation may seem significantly low in retrospect. I view the overall position in THM as rather speculative, but rationally justifiable for a BUY rating. It is definitely not for investors seeking certainty. It is a position for investors who understand that they are buying risk-reward asymmetry here.

data.description:
Fast Facts

YieldMax® SMCI Option Income Strategy ETF (SMCY) is an actively managed ETF launched on 9/11/2024 with a primary objective of current income and a secondary objective of capped exposure to the common stock of Super Micro Computer Inc. (SMCI). SMCY has an expense ratio of 0.99% and an extremely high distribution rate: 85.83%. Distributions are paid on a weekly basis. SMCY is a small, but quite liquid ETF, with $150 million in assets under management and an average daily trading volume of $11 million. The fund’s issuer, YieldMax ETFs, is specialized in options-based income ETFs, including a series of single-stock products such as this one.

Strategy

As described in the prospectus by YieldMax ETFs,

the Fund uses either a synthetic covered call strategy or a synthetic covered call spread strategy to provide income and indirect exposure to the share price returns of SMCI.

This strategy provides income from the option premiums and exposure to the price returns of SMCI with a limit to the upside. The fund doesn’t invest directly in SMCI, only in options based on it.

A covered call strategy consists in investing in an asset and selling (“writing”) one or more call options on it for a premium. In a synthetic covered call strategy, the long position in the asset is replaced with a “synthetic long” using a combination of options designed to replicate the asset’s price return. A synthetic long consists in buying call options and selling put options on the underlying asset with a strike price approximately equal to the asset’s price at the time of initiating the positions. These options typically have one-month to six month terms.

The fund may also use synthetic covered call spreads. Instead of just selling a call against the synthetic long, it will then sell a call and buy another call with a higher strike price for the same expiration date. Buying an additional call reduces the premium income, but also limits the risk of loss on the short call, should the underlying stock price surge beyond expectation.

Additionally, the fund holds treasuries (mostly short term) as collateral for option contracts, which also participates in income generation.

In summary, SMCY executes an options strategy on SMCI to emulate the stock and generate income.

Portfolio

SMCY has 92% of net asset value in cash equivalents and short-term treasuries, and 11 positions in SMCI options, whose notional values are not specified by YieldMax ETFs.

  • A long call and a short put corresponding to a synthetic long expiring on 3/20/2026.
  • Five short calls and four long calls expiring on 3/27/2026 with different strike prices.

Laddering call spreads with different strike prices may reduce the risk compared to having only one. The portfolio composition is an example from 2/26/2026 and may have changed by the time you read this. While the exact holdings and options will change, the strategy remains the same: generating high income writing laddered covered calls.

Fundamentals

Super Micro Computer, the underlying security in SMCY, is classified by GICS in the Information Technology sector and in the Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals industry. Based on Seeking Alpha’s quantitative factor grades, the company has good valuation and growth characteristics, but average momentum and profitability.

Seeking Alpha’s aggregate quantitative ranking puts SMCI in third position in its industry among 27 companies, behind Sandisk Corporation (SNDK) and Dell Technologies Inc. (DELL). SMCY does not provide good exposure to the growth potential of this underlying asset due to the aggressive call strategy designed to produce income.

Historical Performance

SMCY has underperformed SMCI by 12.8% in total return between its inception and 2/26/2026. The fund has a short history and this gap may not be representative of its long term potential.

In this time frame, SMCY shows a 84% loss in share price, partly offset by high distributions. It's total return, like for many similar ETFs, looks better but assumes the reinvestment of these distributions. This NAV decay also impedes a sustainable, growing total return as income is generated on an ever-shrinking asset amount.

NAV erosion is an intrinsic consequence of the asymmetrical option strategy. SMCY fully participates in the downside moves of SMCI through the synthetic long, while its upside is limited by the covered call or cover call spreads. The negative bias is stronger for a volatile stock like SMCI. This pattern will continue in the future, with little or no erosion in slow trends, and steep decay in volatile times.

The distributions were monthly until 10/15/2025, then became weekly. The next two charts show that they have been on a downtrend in both periods, although they have slightly increased in 2026.

This also makes the strategy prone to reverse splits. While it has not undergone a reverse split to date at the time of writing, this is a distinct possibility in the future.

Its income and tax character of return of capital (“ROC”) are very variable: ROC has varied between 0% and 96% in 2026. It may be an issue for tax predictability and has an impact on the net profit of an investment in SMCY.

SMCY is designed for investors seeking to combine income and capital appreciation. The latter may only be achieved by reinvesting a large part of the monthly distribution, based on yield and price trend.

  • Pros: very high yield, weekly distributions, sufficient liquidity.
  • Cons: high expense ratio, short track record, not the best performer in the YieldMax ETF series, underwhelming total return compared to SMCI, variable ROC.

This article answers these three main questions about SMCY:

  1. What is SMCY's purpose and how does it compare to its underlying?
  2. How has SMCY performed compared to similar covered call ETFs?

data.title: FS KKR Capital: Painful Dividend Cut, But Meaningful Discount To NAV Opens Up
data.description:
FS KKR Capital Corp. (FSK) has dipped by more than 15% following a fiscal 2025 fourth quarter earnings report that had a series of setbacks for shareholders, with net investment income dipping year-over-year, net asset value ("NAV') per share seeing erosion, and the dividend being reduced. The business development company ("BDC") just declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.45 per share, a reduction of 29.7% from its prior distribution, and $1.8 per share annualized for a 16% dividend yield. There was also a supplemental distribution of $0.03 per share, for an 1.06% incremental yield when annualized.

FSK had telegraphed this dividend cut, with the BDC now joining a growing list of BDCs that have cut their distributions. This includes BlackRock TCP Capital (TCPC), Golub Capital (GBDC), and Stellus Capital (SCM). The BDC reported fourth quarter net investment income ("NII") of $0.52 per share, a miss of around 2 cents on consensus estimates, and down from $0.57 in the third quarter. This would only have covered the prior base distribution of $0.64 per share by 77.6%. The rightsized dividend is 116% covered. I last covered the ticker in December.

The downstream risk for BDC investors is further dividend cuts as the BDC realizes consecutive quarters of its weighted average annual yield on accruing debt investments dipping. This was 10% as of the end of the fourth quarter, down 50 basis points from the third quarter and from 11% in the year-ago period. This dip in yield has largely been driven by a falling Fed funds rate, with 100 basis points of rate cuts in 2024 followed by 75 basis points of rate cuts in 2025. This was set against a total investment portfolio of $13.01 billion at fair value to 232 companies as of the end of the fourth quarter, with 88.1% of this in floating-rate credit.

The dividend cut against this context reflects the broader macroeconomic backdrop. However, FSK has seen a mild deterioration in lending, with its nonaccrual rate coming in at 3.4% at fair value as of the end of the fourth quarter. This is markedly above the BDC average of around 1.3% at fair value and expanded by 50 basis points sequentially from 2.9% in the third quarter. Nonaccruals were 5.5% of the portfolio on a cost basis.

NAV Discount, Originations, And Credit Quality

The drop in FSK's stock price needs to be contextualized against a quarter that saw a dip in most core metrics. The rise in nonaccruals gives legs to the "credit cockroaches" bearish thesis that there exists a significant amount of zombie companies hidden within private credit. This deterioration in credit quality came with muted originations, with the BDC's portfolio seeing a continued dip versus its prior periods. FSK highlighted that the long-term average cost basis of its nonaccrual rate since 2018 is 1.2%, but this isn't inherently relevant for prospective investors looking to gauge if the current discount to NAV, forced to widen as a response to elevated nonaccruals, represents an opportunity or liability. FSK's NAV ended the fourth quarter at $20.89 per share, down around $1.1 per share from the second quarter. The BDC took a NAV hit from the prior lack of coverage, with a $0.89 per share hit also seen from net realized losses. The commons at $11.22 per share are trading for a 46% discount to NAV.

The meaningful discount to NAV per share that has opened up is among the steepest in FSK's history. To what extent it provides a healthy baseline for a new long position in the commons will depend on the BDC's ability to bring nonaccruals back in line with the industry average. Net investment activity was negative at $234 million, with sales and redemptions of $1.33 billion running ahead of originations of $1.09 billion. This presents more downside risk for NII as FSK will face tighter yields on a smaller portfolio. The dividend yield has moved to its highest ever level on the back of a prior lack of NII coverage, with the common shares seeing a 51% retracement over the last 1-year.

Conclusion

FSK's dividend cut, lack of cadence with originations, and large discount to NAV per share all reflect a difficult quarter for the BDC. I'm worried about the rise in nonaccruals, as this highlights a more fundamental dip in the quality of its underwriting. While the AI-driven fears around software have dented sentiment in BDCs, FSK did actually clock in a quarter that needs to be dramatically improved on. However, the current dividend is large and covered, so it could provide a baseline for new investors. I am rating FSK as a Hold.

data.title: Powell Industries: The Price Level I Load Up At
data.description:
Introduction & Investment Thesis

Powell Industries (POWL) had a massive rally since the start of the year, with the stock up 64% YTD, hugely outperforming the S&P 500’s 1.5% gain during this period of time.

Part of the reason behind the rally could be attributed to the company’s positioning as a diversified manufacturer of electrical distribution products and systems, as we witness one of the most aggressive AI buildouts that requires massive investments in power generation and grid modernization.

This was reflected in the company’s Q1 FY26 earnings, where New Orders and Backlog grew 63% and 16% YoY, respectively, which caught everyone by surprise. Out of the $1.6B in total backlog, Electric Utility and Commercial & Other Industrial contributed over half at a combined $824M as order activity accelerated in their data center end market, with larger project sizes and the company winning its first $75M (megaproject) deal in the end market.

With management optimistic on the FY26 outlook of its end markets, analysts have revised their forward growth projections that point to the company accelerating both its revenue and earnings until FY28. Meanwhile, the forward P/E ratio has also expanded over 73% since the time of my last writing, reflecting growing investor optimism in the company’s growth prospects.

While the successful execution of its backlog is key, along with monitoring for potential order cancellation, I am bullish on the long-term prospects of the company as well.

Having said that, I believe that the price action is extended at the moment and will therefore wait for a better entry point, closer to the 10Wk level at $460 per share that would expand the size of my upside potential towards my price target of $585 per share.

Strength in Electric Utility and Oil & Gas segments boosts revenue by 4% YoY

Powell Industries reported their Q1 FY26 earnings at the start of February, where the company grew its revenues and earnings per share by 4% and 18.8%, respectively.

On the revenue front, Powell generated $251.2M in total revenue, with strength in its Electric Utility and Oil & Gas markets that contribute 35% and 2%, respectively, contributing over 66.5% of Total Revenue. Note that Oil & Gas continues to be the largest revenue segment of Powell Industries; however, the contribution from Electric Utility has expanded over 630 basis points on a year-over-year basis.

Meanwhile, their Commercial & other industrial and Petrochemical segments saw a year-over-year decline in revenues of 8.2% and 31.3%, respectively, which probably explains why the company missed their revenue estimates for the quarter by a little over 2%.

When it comes to profitability, gross margins expanded on a year-over-year basis by 370 basis points to 28.4%, which management attributed to favorable volume leverage, strong project execution, and a stable pricing environment, while earnings per share beat estimates as well.

Record-Breaking New Orders & Backlog Growth Drive Optimism

The reason, however, the stock surged after earnings is tied to its New Orders and Backlog growth.

Let me further elaborate.

During the quarter, Powell’s New Orders grew 63% YoY to $439M, which was their highest quarterly total in over two years, with widespread activity across oil and gas, data centers, and the electric utilities markets. This is compared to just 1% growth in New Orders to $271M in Q4 FY25.

As management discussed on the earnings call, New Orders from their Commercial & Other Industrial market accelerated, accounting for almost 50% of their total awards during the quarter as the average project size is growing substantially along with the company’s first megaproject order of approximately $75M in the data center end market. Particularly, when it comes to their Data Center end market within the Commercial & Other Industrial business segment, new orders exceeded $100M, accounting for over 22% of Total New Orders.

This is also reflected in their backlog, which grew 16% YoY to $1.6B, out of which 60% or so is expected to convert into revenue over the next 12 months. This is compared to just a 3% YoY increase in backlog to $1.4B in Q4 FY25.

As you can see in the image below, Powell’s backlog growth has been driven by Electric Utility and Commercial & Other Industrial markets, now accounting for 30% and 22%, respectively, or over half of total backlog at $824M for the first time ever. Note that out of the 22% backlog contribution from Commercial & Other Industrial market segment, data centers account for roughly 15% of the backlog, both of which are record levels for Powell Industries.

This fits into management’s optimism on Powell’s position as a diversified manufacturer of electrical distribution products and systems amid a secular and durable growth trend that involves “a growing and broad investment in power generation and grid modernization to support data center and AI capacity growth, domestic manufacturing, electrification, and the export of energy resources like LNG.”

Forward growth Estimates Revised Higher; Price Multiples Expand Faster

The sudden surge in New Orders and Backlog quickly got translated into analysts revising their forward growth projections higher for revenue and earnings. To further support the upward revisions was the positive management commentary during the earnings call, where they were optimistic on the outlook for all their major end markets.

Starting with their largest Oil & Gas market, management discussed that the fundamentals for the US natural gas market continue to support their investments in LNG as project activity remains robust. When it comes to their Electric Utility market, management pointed to the growing wave of investment in electrical infrastructure, which positions Powell Industries to capture another year of strong activity in the segment. What was also encouraging was the acceleration of order activity in the data center end market, which gives Powell Industries’ management the confidence to further grow their presence.

At the moment, analysts are projecting Powell Industries to grow their revenues by 7.78% YoY in FY26, followed by acceleration in revenue growth rate every single year until FY28 to $1.51B, indicating the structural and durable nature of the demand in their end markets that is not expected to fade anytime soon. As you can also see, the magnitude of upward revision to FY27 and FY28 revenue expectations is much higher compared to that of FY26.

This is similar to the forward earnings growth rate projections, which have been significantly raised for FY26 and beyond. Similar to the revenue trend, earnings acceleration is not expected to slow down at least until FY28, when Powell Industries is expected to generate $21.56 in earnings per share.

The stock is currently trading at a forward non-GAAP PE ratio of 33. Note that the PE ratio has expanded over 73% since the time of my previous writing, when the stock was trading at a non-GAAP PE ratio of 19. During the same period of time, the forward earnings per share for FY26 have been revised higher by over 7%. In other words, most of the gain in the stock price during this period of time has been primarily driven by multiple expansion, driven by renewed investor optimism on the company’s forward growth prospects after the 63% YoY surge in New Orders.

Another way to look at it is that even though Powell’s forward PE ratio based on FY26 earnings per share projection has risen considerably higher, it compresses down to 25.5 when taking FY28 earnings per share into account. This is just 16% higher than the sector median at 21.52, which is reasonable, in my opinion, for a company that is projected to see both a revenue and earnings per share acceleration into FY28.

In fact, if we take the S&P 500 as a proxy, where its 10-year average PE ratio stands at 18.8, for companies growing their earnings on average by 9% annually, I believe Powell Industries deserves to trade at 1.4x given that its earnings are projected to grow at roughly 13% over the next three years.

This will translate to a PE ratio of 27, or a price target of $583 per share, that represents an upside of 6% from current levels.

Can these estimates be revised higher upon further New Order strength ahead? Absolutely.

But what about the risk of order cancellations or capacity not being able to meet the backlog?

This is what we will discuss next.

Risks & Conclusions

During the earnings call, management discussed that they are taking measures to expand productive capacity to ensure the execution and delivery of their project backlog, which include “adding additional leased facilities to support the expansion of production lines, increased inventory needs, and broader collaboration with their supply base to ramp supply and improve cycle times as well as rebalancing and reallocating the manufacture of select products across our facilities in North America.”

Meanwhile, the expansion of their Jacintoport facility is on track to be completed by H2 FY26, which will serve all of their end markets, particularly their Oil & Gas customers, where they anticipate large-scale LNG project development work to come over the next 3-5 years.

When asked about how the management is thinking about ramping up capex in the coming years, the management briefly discussed that they are evaluating a potential $100M investment in a new facility to support multiyear growth. Note that the company has a $500M cash balance, which is more than sufficient to fund higher capex investments so that the company can continue to expand their capacity to fulfill both their current backlog and position to capture forward demand.

Aside from ensuring that Powell has the necessary capacity to fulfill the execution of their current backlog, there is also the possibility of potential order cancellation, as management pointed out is "a future concern that’s on their radar" and can add significant volatility to forward growth projections.

In the meantime, I also view that the stock price is currently extended after the 72% YTD rally, with its weekly RSI at close to 75.

So, while I am bullish on the company’s long-term prospects, I will not be chasing the rally.

Instead, I will wait for some more consolidation in the stock price. Ideally, I would like for the stock to correct to its 10Wk at roughly $460 per share, which would represent a downside risk of close to 15% from current levels. At that point, I may consider initiating a position, as the size of my potential upside would have expanded from 6% at current levels to over 20%, making the risk-reward more attractive.

The Dividend Yield Theory approach

Dividend Yield Theory is a valuable approach to finding companies that promise good total return through a combination of dividend growth and share price appreciation. It begins by identifying well-established companies that appear undervalued based on a yield that is markedly higher than historical levels. In most cases the high yield is the result of a low share price. DYT then determines the likelihood of price and yield returning to previous levels based on company strength, resources, and the state of their industry.This determination is made by examining business metrics like:

  • S&P quality
  • Dividend growth rate
  • Price/earnings ratio
  • Payout ratio
  • Return on invested capital
  • Free cash flow
  • Free cash flow yield

If the assessment is correct, the company recovers, and the yield returns to its mean, the investors benefit from both a resurgent share price and the higher yields during the recovery period. DYT concentrates on large companies with a proven business model. It is a long term strategy, with a timeline of years (4-5 years is a common time frame). The returns, however are large enough to be worth the wait.

Anyone interested in going further into DYT can look at the Investment Quality Trends site, the World of Dividends blog, or my earlier reports on Hershey (HSY) and Merck (MRK), and FactSet Data Systems (FDS).

Brown-Forman Corporation

Brown-Forman Corporation (BF.B) is one of the largest spirits companies in the world. It has $4 billion in annual revenue, operates globally and has some of the most recognized products in the industry, including Jack Daniels, Old Forester, Woodford, Diplomatico, Suntory, and Chambord. It was founded in 1870 and has increased its dividend for 42 years.

On a share price basis the company presents an intriguing scenario. For two decades, from 2000 through 2020, long term investors were every pleased as the stock went on a steady climb from about $6 to $80 per share. Since then, however, it has just as steadily fallen as low as $26, for a decline of 67%. Is this a buying opportunity, or is the company in trouble from which there is no return? Brown-Forman is facing significant challenges that they have not encountered before. CEO Lawson Whiting acknowledged the threats from GLP-1 drugs, cannabis, and Gen-Z’s comparatively lower alcohol consumption, and US alcohol is a fat target in the tariff wars. When we look at the key DYT statistic, historical yield, it’s necessary to go back decades to determine a range. The yield was persistently low while the share price had its lengthy rise, even as the dividend grew 50% over the period. Only when we look 2 years does a range become clear (the 2007 spike comes from a $1.65/share special dividend).

Using this timeline, we can proceed with a Dividend Yield Theory analysis. Excluding the 2007 special dividend, the yield range is from 0.90% to 3.55% with a mean of about 1.8%.

The current environment

The outlook for Brown-Forman is being determined by three main factors:

Tariffs

Whiskey tariffs have long been a way for other countries to flex their trade muscles against the US. There was a 25% tariff from 2018-2022, a 50% tariff threatened last year, and currently a 15% tariff in the EU and other countries. The 2018 tariffs caused a 25% drop in international sales and estimates are for -15% under current tariffs. This is meaningful, since foreign sales account for 55% of revenue. The popularity of tariffs as a trade weapon also creates ongoing uncertainty, which always reduces investor enthusiasm.

International sales environment

Although sales typically rebound when tariffs are removed, the current situation is not typical. In addition to an unexpected and harsh general tariff regime, the Trump administration’s foreign policy has caused ill will in many of our trading partners. So, for example, Canada has a 25% tariff on US alcohol, but sales there have plummeted 60%, far more than an expectation from tariffs alone. Some provinces have stopped selling US alcohol entirely. Much of the motivation for buying alcohol comes from a brand’s cachet, which in the case of American whiskey is very strong. When this is severely damaged, as it is now, it can take a long time to be repaired.

The strength of the dollar also has an effect on international results. The dollar has declined about 10% over the past year, which hurts the top and bottom lines when foreign sales are converted to USD.

There are two main trends in this decline: 1) changing drinking behavior, and 2) cannabis consumption.

Americans are drinking less. According to Gallup (and others), the percentage of Americans who drink alcohol was stable for most of this century, but has markedly declined from 67% in 2022 to 54% in 2025. The change has been attributed to health awareness, changing social norms, and the impact of the pandemic. This is even more marked for young adults, like Generation Z, who seem to have a different relationship with alcohol than their elders. Adding to this are the new generation of weight-loss drugs, which have been shown to reduce the desire for alcohol. These trends appear to be a major cultural shift. They have already had an impact on Brown-Forman and its peers, and are observed outside the US as well. If they prove durable the impact will be long term. Adding to this is the new generation of weight-loss drugs, which have been shown to reduce the desire for alcohol. With nearly 12 percent of Americans having used GLP-1 drugs for weight loss so far, this exacerbates the lower consumption trend.

Cannabis has emerged as a big competitor to alcohol in recent years: Domestic cannabis sales reached $23.9 billion in 2025, and it is legal in 40 states. For many people cannabis has replaced alcohol, whether it be for sleep, social reasons, or just intoxication. When a person consumes cannabis, they aren’t drinking. The massive hole this creates in the alcohol market is only going to get bigger as the US cannabis market continues to grow.

Every company faces challenges, and their long term success depends on meeting those challenges successfully. Unfortunately, there’s little in Brown-Forman’s recent history to suggest they will do this. Revenues and earnings have been dropping, and the company expects another single digit decline this year. Acquisition of other brands is a tried and true strategy in the industry, but Brown-Forman’s acquisitions results have been mixed at best. New products like Blackberry Jack have not been enough to move the needle. The path to future growth is very unclear. Instead, they have been retrenching, closing their barrel-making facility and idling a distillery.

Brown-Forman Summary and Investing Recommendation

Recommendation: HOLD. According to Dividend Yield Theory, Brown-Forman has a potential total return of 86.7% over the next four or five years. DYT usually highlights companies with problems, and it takes courage and a solid bull case to commit money to them. However, the obstacles facing BF, led by a customer base that is drinking less, cast doubt about a successful turnaround in growth or a return to previous highs. The challenges are long term and substantial, and management does not seem to have a convincing long term strategy to address them. It's appropriate to keep currently owned shares, because there is a profitable level of base business that could improve if trends change, and the company is shareholder-friendly in terms of share buybacks and dividend increases. However, the path to a return to historical levels of business and stock prices is not clear, and there are companies with more potential elsewhere.

data.title: TJX Companies: I Prefer It Over Ross Stores - Just Not At 30x
data.description:
Not long ago, I analyzed Ross Stores (ROST), and basically, I mentioned that I really liked the business model because of its resilience, but at the time, I wasn't very comfortable with the valuation. Since then, ROST stock has risen about 18%. TJX Companies (TJX) has followed more or less the same path.

And the TJX model is also compelling to me, basically as the CEO said: the company can prove that in-store shopping is still very solid. And even though Q4 earnings prove this well, I am still very cautious about the margin of safety issue. The current premium on TJX is as if it were a company that you would have to really want to have in your portfolio to accept paying that price, and for me, that is not the case. That is why I am going with a hold rating for TJX stock.

Q4 Earnings: TJX Showed Resilience

The CEO described the quarter as “excellent,” but I only agree in part. It was indeed a very solid Q4, and I liked the comp sales of ~5%, but on the earnings call, that number was described as “very strong.” I don't know if it's that strong; to me, it's more like okay, very solid. But in any case, considering that the landscape is not the best, it is indeed a positive performance.

In fact, it seems to me to be an endorsement that this treasure hunt experience is as resilient as we imagined and as history would suggest. Especially since TJX's 10-year CAGR for revenue is almost 7%, the same for EBIT and EBITDA, which grew by an average of 6.9% per year. And that, with a few buybacks and better net income, caused EPS to compound in double digits.

But back to the quarter, the comparable sales mix was also quite interesting in my view. In Q4 last year, Marmaxx's performance was slightly worse, and TJX Canada and TJX International drove performance up. Now, we saw the same number for comp sales (~5%), but with slightly stronger performance from Marmaxx and HomeGoods in the U.S.

We are talking about comp sales, but as TJX continued to expand, net sales increased 9% YoY, and the pretax profit margin increased 1.9 pps, causing EPS to increase by more than 20%. It is really a very good performance.

Another thing I liked to see was the mentions in the earnings call of TJX's initiatives. They mentioned that they are remodeling stores and new store prototypes, in addition to more aggressive marketing, all to maintain this high growth we are seeing. All of this makes it possible to be confident that TJX will continue to be a compounder in the coming years. The execution is very good, there are new initiatives to run, and the business model remains intact and minimally protected from the macroeconomic scenario and other passing trends such as fashion, which is difficult to predict.

TJX: Great Is Quite Different From Perfect

I don't think Q4 earnings were bad, or that TJX's business model has deteriorated, far from it. But I think we should separate the great from the perfect. The prospects are good, but there are still risks and uncertainties. For example, all these initiatives that TJX is undertaking are really great, but they carry execution risk. If the marketing campaign is too aggressive and does not deliver the expected top-line results, it could put pressure on margins, just as new store prototypes may not be so well received by an already loyal customer base.

The reason I am saying this is not because I want TJX to stop in time; I want them to carry out these initiatives. It is just to bring us back to reality. This is a retail company like any other; TJX has its moats and everything else, but it is not untouchable. Yes, macro sensitivity is much lower here, but the company can still suffer from crises and tariffs, for instance, as the company mentioned that it is “evaluating the potential impact of last Friday’s ruling on tariffs.”

And that totally goes against the valuation. Here we are no longer talking about TJX stock being a bargain; we are talking about a quality company that trades at a quality premium.

For the current fiscal year, we are talking about a P/E of 30x, the same as ROST. Considering the next fiscal year, the P/E goes to 27x, slightly lower than ROST, and as TJX is growing slightly more than Ross, this seems good. But looking at the multiples in isolation, I don't like it very much.

27x earnings means a potential earnings yield of ~3.5%, and for revenue and net income that should grow in the high single digits in the long term, it seems fair, reasonable but far from compelling.

Does a company that will compound EPS at 8% or 9% per year deserve to be traded at 27x earnings? In my opinion, maybe. If we are talking about a Costco (COST), I think it is reasonable. If the uncertainties, risks, and competitive environment are greater, then I cannot be so optimistic, and I think that is the case with TJX.

This is worse when compared to its own history. TJX's average forward P/E is 25x, and it is currently at the 27x-30x I mentioned (depending on which fiscal year you look at). It is a premium that in some multiples reaches 20% to 30% of TJX stock's own history.

And if you think it is managing to grow, maybe it really deserves that premium. But personally, I prefer to buy when there is a discount, whether due to some temporary fear or just lower market sentiment towards the sector, perhaps when there is some kind of rotation again, making these quality names cheaper.

In fact, if we look at the chart below, we can see that TJX has already (not long ago) traded at 20x earnings (and that's TTM, not forward), so I prefer to keep an eye on these moments, which, in my opinion, are bound to happen eventually.

The Bottom Line

I believe my hold rating here makes a lot of sense. On the one hand, it shows that I like the case, since TJX is a great company, cash cow, etc. But at the same time, it shows that at these prices, I'm not a buyer.

I also don't think that the valuation makes it a sell; there isn't such a bad negative asymmetry - it's close to fair. So I prefer to stay on the sidelines and wait. That's why I'm starting my TJX coverage with a hold rating.

data.title: Neptune Insurance: Riding Flood Insurance Regulatory Tailwinds
data.description:
Investment Thesis

Neptune Insurance Holdings Inc. (NP) is a newly listed insurance agent benefiting from multiple regulatory and market tailwinds pushing demand for flood insurance higher. Mortgage lenders are increasingly asking borrowers to insure properties against flood, thus protecting the collateral against the mortgage. New regulations are increasing the appeal of private flood insurance versus the National Flood Insurance Program "NFIP," the largest player on the market today. Finally, NP benefits from a first-mover advantage as the first large-scale insurance agent.

Unique Market

The flood insurance market is dominated by the Federal Government through NFIP, a program created in the late 1960s to fill a coverage gap against floods, a catastrophic event risk that is hard to insure.

Neptune isn't an insurer, but it underwrites flood policies to private insurers who compete with NFIP. Thus, the program and its scope have an impact on NP. One can say that NFIP is a competitor to NP and its "capacity providers" — the name NP gives for its private insurance customers/partners who buy the insurance policies it underwrites.

I don't expect NFIP to end anytime soon. However, regulators recognize the financial burden of the program on the federal budget. It has been living on congressional extensions for some time now, as opposed to a permanent budget.

Regulatory Tailwinds

NFIP has been offering subsidized flood insurance for decades. In 2021, regulators decided that it was time for NFIP to start charging market rates. The new premium prices won't rise overnight. The maximum amount an existing insurance policy will increase is capped at 18% annually. Since the gap between what NFIP charges and the "fair price" is large, it will take multiple years at this rate for the premiums to reach this fair market level. As premiums start to increase, the appeal of NFIP insurance will start to diminish. This will help NP increase its market penetration.

In 2023, the Government Accountability Office "GAO" conducted a study that found that 66% of NFIP policies will have to increase to reach a fair market price that reflects the risk. 31% of total NFIP's policies would increase by more than 100% to match FEMA's risk 2.0 methodology. FEMA started Risk 2.0 in October 2021. That means that even if these policies increased by 18% annually, many are yet to reach the market price, i.e., 18% since October 2021 is 72% increase.

Impressive Growth

Yesterday, NP uploaded its first 10-K filing to the SEC (annual report), showing impressive growth. In FY'25, revenue stood at $159.5 million, up 34% YoY. GAAP net income was up 8%; however, this figure was impacted by multiple one-time items tied to the IPO, such as the deal's professional expenses ($9 million) and an $11.1 million jump in SBC costs after NP's shares became public. Overall, adjusted net income stood at $56.9 million, up 37.6% YoY (p.71).

Adding to NP's moat is the quality of its earnings due to visibility. NP isn't an insurer. It underwrites the insurance policy and manages it on behalf of a capacity provider. It earns recurring revenue for both services on a continuous basis. As long as the policy is renewed, NP will continue earning fees as a % of the premium paid, while passing the reset to the capacity provider as compensation for taking the actual risk of the policy. In 2025, 67.9% of revenue came from renewed past policies. Overall, the company boasts a renewal rate of 86.1%, meaning that customers see value in the policies they were sold.

Based on the loss ratio of NP's policies, it seems that it is delivering value for its capacity providers as well. The company's policies are less costly compared to NFIP's policies. This is demonstrated by the lower loss ratio during catastrophic events, as shown in the chart below. In 2025, NP ended the year with 40 capacity providers, up from 23 in the prior year. This demonstrates the value that the company brings to both buyers and sellers.

Valuation

The Wall Street consensus non-GAAP EPS for this year is $0.52. In 2025, diluted adjusted EPS stood at $0.41 (p.71). Thus, this year's EPS forecast implies a deceleration of growth, down to 19.2% YoY, compared to 32.3% in 2025.

FY'26e FY'25 FY'24
Adjusted EPS (diluted) $0.52 $0.41 $0.31

Is this because of the law of large numbers? I believe yes. The average diluted shares outstanding as of December 2025 stood at 140,041,763. Using this figure as a proxy for FY'26 shares, and multiplying by the consensus $0.52/share FY'26e EPS results in a net income forecast of $72.8 million. In absolute terms, that's $15.9 million more than FY'25's adjusted income (which stood at $56.9 million). For perspective, the absolute growth in adjusted income between FY'25 and FY'24 was $15.5 million. These figures suggest that NP is growing at the same cadence, but the growth rate is different because of the law of large numbers.

In terms of valuation, a $0.52 EPS translates to a forward P/E of 41x. This isn't exactly cheap when compared to the financial sector. But at the same time, NP has certain characteristics that support a higher valuation, namely the flywheel effect of its Triton insurance writing software, which learns from each insurance policy it underwrites, collecting data to price policies more accurately.

I think the closest comparison to NP that I've recently covered is Accelerant Holdings (ARX). Both run an AI-powered, data-centric, insurance General Managing Agent "GMA" services that funnel policies to "Capacity Providers" or "Risk Capital Partners" as Accelerant likes to call the insurance companies "buying" its policies. However, there is an important difference. Accelerant retains about 10% of the policies it underwrites. On the other hand, NP is a pure, capital-light, GMA service provider. Is this enough to explain the valuation difference between the two? Accelerant has a forward P/E ratio of 13x. That's a fraction of NP's valuation.

Risks

NP's above-average valuation increases the bar it needs to hit to maintain its price levels. Growth seems already baked into the price, and execution needs to be near perfect. This bullish rating assumes investors have the capacity to withstand volatile trading and hold through the long term as NP delivers on growth and exceeds what's already baked in the price. The market is nascent, unlocked by FEMA's Risk 2.0 initiative, which is still unfolding. Intel Market Research estimates the value of the Flood Market at $13.2 billion in 2025. NFIP holds 4.7 million insurance policies with $4.6 billion in annual premiums. For perspective, NP holds 280,000 policies in force with an annual premium of $367 million (p.68). This leaves NP with a lot of growth runway.

Another risk to consider is the exposure to economic cycles. If, for any reason, the capacity providers decided not to take on flood policies, NP's business will suffer. Also, NP could face reputation damage if its capacity partners don't fulfill their coverage promises. Although NP doesn't provide coverage, it is the customer-facing agent.

Final Thoughts

I think NP offers a unique growth opportunity in the Flood insurance market. Regulatory tailwinds support a buy thesis for long-term investors. NFIP, the largest flood insurance provider, isn't popular among politicians concerned about the government's debt and budget. NFIP isn't profitable, unlike other government-sponsored entities such as the Federal National Mortgage Association (FNMA) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (FMCC). I believe that the smaller NFIP gets, the happier many lawmakers will be.

However, this brings us to a critical political concern. As of now, agents and insurance companies can refuse to underwrite a policy if it is risky. Thus, the possibility of cherry picking exists. It is possible that NP picks low-risk policies and sends the "bad apples" to NFIP. In the past, the federal government implemented laws that prevented this kind of behavior in certain insurance markets, particularly health insurance.

In the most extreme case, the private market may “cherry-pick” (i.e., adversely select against the NFIP) the profitable, lower-risk NFIP policies that are “overpriced” either due to cross-subsidization or imprecise flood insurance rate structures, particularly when there is pricing inefficiency in favor of the customer. Congressional Research Service (p.15).

The Affordable Care Act limited the ability of health insurance companies to refuse to write policies based on the health of the individual. This made it very hard to "cherry-pick" customers in large segments of the healthcare sector. One can imagine a similar policy being implemented in the Flood insurance market.
